IX 


Introduction 


The  Holy  Koran  has  become  a  focal  point  of  scholarly  interest  in  the  United 
States — one  facet  of  a  broader  interest  that  extends  to  Islam  in  general.  The 
growing  concern  of  American  scholars  and  theologians  with  Islamic  and  Arabic 
studies,  combined  with  the  expanding  attraction  to  the  interdisciplinary  study 
of  foreign  areas  and  religions,  have  led  to  a  proliferation  of  publications  on  these 
subjects. 

The  present  bibliography,  selected  from  the  vast  Koranic  holdings  of  the 
Library  of  Congress,  is  designed  to  guide  the  scholarly  and  general  public  in  the 
use  of  significant  books  and  journals  dealing  with  The  Holy  Koran  and  Koranic 
studies. 

The  guide  is  divided  into  five  major  parts:  (1)  a  listing  of  manuscripts  of 
The  Holy  Koran,  facsimile,  and  tafsir  (i.e.,  commentaries  on  The  Holy  Koran); 
(2)  printed  texts  of  The  Holy  Koran  in  the  original  Arabic,  the  language  in  which 
it  was  revealed  to  the  Prophet  Muhammad;  (3)  interpretations  (translations)  in 
forty  languages;  (4)  citations  on  The  Holy  Koran  in  special  formats,  particularly 
microfilm  and  sound  recordings;  and  (5)  studies  about  The  Holy  Koran,  both 
books  and  articles,  in  a  number  of  languages.  Since  the  holdings  of  the  Library 
are  immense  in  this  area,  the  works  selected  have  been  limited  to  titles  that  are 
considered  of  basic  significance  for  the  understanding  of  the  different  aspects 
and  concerns  of  Koranic  studies.  Citations  to  articles  in  Arabic  were  taken  from 
Majallat  al-Azhar,  1930-19881,  an  authoritative  source  of  Sunni  Islam,  while 
Index  Islamicus,  1906-19882,  was  a  primary  source  for  references  to  non-Arabic 
articles.  All  periodical  sources  have  been  checked  against  the  Library's  holdings. 
This  part  also  lists  doctoral  dissertations  in  English,  French,  and  German,  based 
on  citations  gathered  from  Dissertation  Abstracts  International3;  Arabic  and 


'Majallat  al-Azhar,  1 930- 1 988. —Cairo:  al-Jami'  al-Azhar,  1930-1988.  [BP1.C3 
Orien  Arab] 

2  Index  Islamicus,  1906-1955  /  compiled  by  J.  D.  Pearson  with  the  assistance  of  Julia 
F.  Ashton. — London:  University.  School  of  Oriental  and  African  studies,  1958;  with 
supplements.  [Z7835.M6L6] 

3  Dissertation  Abstracts  International. — [Ann  Arbor,  Mich.]:  University  Microfilms, 
V.1-,  1938-.  [Title  and  frequency  varies].  [Z5053.D57] 

xi 


Islamic  studies*;  American  Doctoral  Dissertations  on  the  Arab  World5,  and  the 
Library  of  Congress  catalogs.  The  tafsir  (commentaries)  and  Koranic  studies, 
whether  manuscripts  or  printed  materials,  are  arranged  alphabetically;  the  other 
parts  are  arranged  in  chronological  order. 

The  Library  of  Congress  transliteration  systems  have  been  used  throughout. 
Whenever  a  variation  to  these  systems  occurs,  added  entries  and  cross-references 
are  given.  Place  names  in  imprints  have  been  converted  into  Western  usage 
without  regard  to  the  form  in  which  the  name  is  given  in  the  publication.  In  a 
few  cases,  however,  the  transliterated  form  has  been  applied.  This  publication 
includes  indexes  by  personal  name,  title,  subject,  and  series. 

I  wish  to  express  my  thanks  to  all  those  who  have  assisted  me  in  this 
bibliography.  I  owe  hearty  thanks  to  Dr.  George  N.  Atiyeh,  head,  Near  East 
Section,  and  to  Lloyd  Gedra,  Emeritus  Librarian,  for  thier  help  and  for  the 
numerous  appropriate  suggestions,  of  which  I  have  gladly  availed  myself. 
Thanks  are  due  to  Dr.  Julian  W.  Witherell,  chief  of  the  African  and  Middle 
Eastern  Divisions  at  the  time  this  bibliography  was  compiled,  for  his  encourage- 
ment; and  to  Dr.  Hamad  I.  al-Sallum,  Cultural  Attache,  Embassy  of  Saudi 
Arabia,  Washington,  D.C.,  for  his  financial  support  for  the  printing  of  full-color 
illustrations;  the  Educational  Technology  Center  and  its  director,  Dr.  FawzT 
Zahir,  at  the  University  of  Qatar,  Doha,  Qatar,  for  designing  the  Arabic  title 
page;  to  the  late  Dr.  Muhammad  I.  Kazim,  UNESCO  Regional  Coordinator 
for  the  Arab  States  and  Director  of  UNEDBAS,  and  to  the  late  Dr.  'Aziz  S. 
'Ativan,  Director,  Middle  East  Center,  University  of  Utah,  for  their  help  during 
the  time  I  worked  under  their  supervision. 

Many  thanks  are  also  due  to  Staffan  Rosenborg  and  Johanna  Craig  in  the 
Library's  Publishing  Office,  for  their  careful  and  sympathetic  editing,  and  to 
Irene  Fanous  for  her  assistance.  Finally,  I  am  honored  to  acknowledge  my 
particular  obligation  and  sincerest  appreciation,  which  cannot  be  adequately 
expressed,  to  Dr.  cAbd  Allah  J.  al-KubaysI,  President,  University  of  Qatar,  for 
his  constant  support  and  inspiration. 

Fawzi  Mikhail  Tadros 
December  1989

XXIX 


Koran — Manuscripts 


Whole  Manuscripts 


1 

Qur'an  (Mss) 

321  folios,  15.5  x  15.7  cm.,  12  lines  in  NaskhT  script  with  black  diacritical 
marks.  First  two  pages  illuminated.  Writing  is  on  white  paper  but  pink  col- 
ored papers  are  affixed  to  margins  throughout.  Surahs  in  white  on  gold  back- 
ground. Margins  ruled  in  gold  and  colors.  Illuminated  devices  on  margins 
throughout.  Binding  in  brown  leather  with  stamped  designs  on  margin  and 
center.  Copied  by  Muhammad  Shukr  Allah  Ibrahim  AbadI  Shakir  'Abd  al- 
Baql  Had!  al-HarawT.  SM73 

2 

Qur'an  (Mss) 

251  folios,  9x16  cm.,  15  lines  to  a  page  in  Ta'llq  script  with  diacritical 
marks  in  black. 

The  first  and  last  few  pages  missing.  Pages  ruled  in  red  and  verses  sepa- 
rated by  gold  discs.  Front  cover  missing.  Back  cover  stamped  with  medallion 
in  center.  Probably  from  the  tenth/sixteenth  century. 

3 

Qur'an  (Mss) 

Unpaged,  15  x  20  cm.,  17  lines  in  Maghrib!  script  with  diacritical  marks  in 
red.  SM91 

An  incomplete  Koran  with  loose  leaves,  stained  all  over  but  legible.  Brown 
leather  binding.  A  plan  of  the  tomb  of  the  Prophet  Muhammad  in  Medina 
placed  at  the  end.  Probably  twelfth/eighteenth  century. 

4 

Qur'an  (Mss) 

390  folios,  10.5  x  18  cm.,  14  lines  in  NaskhT  script  with  diacritical  marks 
in  black.  Probably  thirteenth  century  from  the  Caucasian  region.  Titles  of 
surahs  in  red.  Verses  separated  by  gilt  circles.  Margins  ruled  in  gold  and  blue. 
First  two  pages  illuminated  with  gold,  blue  and  red,  but  colors  are  brownish 
or  faded.  Margins  of  some  pages  decorated  with  gilt  floral  designs.  Brown 

1 


cover  and  flap  with  gilt  designs  with  central  medallions  and  cornerpieces  deco- 
rated with  gilt  filigrees.  Some  cornerpieces  worn.  SM87 

5 

Qur'an  (Mss) 

470  folios,  17.7  x  27.8  cm.,  12  lines  in  Naskhl  script.  First  two  pages  and 
last  two  pages  together  with  the  pages  of  Surat  Bani  Isra'il  (The  Children  of 
Israel)  profusely  illuminated  in  gold,  blue  and  pink  colors.  Titles  of  surahs 
written  in  blue  on  gold  background.  Borders  and  lines  in  gold.  Verses  sepa- 
rated by  gold  circles.  Medallions  in  gold  and  color  mark  divisions.  Laquered 
binding,  Cashmere  work,  seventeenth  century.  SM93 

6 

Qur'an  (Mss) 

304  folios,  22  x  30.4  cm.,  13  lines  in  Masahif  script.  First  two  pages  illumi- 
nated. Part  of  the  illumination  faded.  Surahs  are  written  in  red.  The  number 
of  verses  and  rhymes  are  in  yellow  and  green  surrounded  by  red.  SM94 

Gilt  medallions  on  margins  mark  devisions.  First  few  pages  are  supplied  by 
a  later  hand.  Cover  with  flap  is  decorated  in  gold.  This  Qur'an  was  repaired 
by  mounting  folios  on  strong  European  paper.  First  page  has  endowment 
dated  1042/1632. 

7 

Qur'an  (Mss)

Qur'an  (Mss)

Kemal  Pasha,  the  Ottoman  ambassador  to  Persia. 


Manuscript  Fragments 


18 

Qur'an  (Mss).  Fragment. 

57  folios,  8.5  x  14  cm.,  6  lines  to  a  page  in  Kufic  script  on  vellum  with 
diacritical  marks  in  red.  SM83 

This  rare  and  unusual  manuscript  comes  probably  from  the  fifth/eleventh 
century  and  begins  in  the  middle  of  verses  28  of  Sural  al-Qasas  (The  Story) 
and  ends  at  the  beginning  of  Surat  Saba  (Saba',  "Sheba").  The  last  four 
pages  are  discolored.  Surahs  written  in  gold.  Circular  designs  in  gold  on  some 
margins.  Binding  recent. 

19 

Qur'an  (Mss).  Fragment. 

38  folios,  9  x  12  cm.,  8  lines  to  a  page  in  broken  bent  Kufic  script  with 
diacritics.  SM84 


This  probably  unique  copy  of  the  Qur'an  on  parchment  comes  from  the 
fifth/eleventh  century.  It  begins  with  verse  40  of  Surat  al-Anfal  (Spoils  of 
War).  Binding  in  brown  leather  with  stamped  medallion  in  center.  Inside 
cover  has  a  rare  four  semi-circular  shaped  forms  placed  opposite  each  other. 

20 

Qur'an  (Mss).  Fragment. 

47  folios,  16  x  23  cm.,  7  lines  to  a  page  (Arabic)  with  diacritical  marks  in 
black  and  7  interlinear  lines  in  the  Persian  translation  in  red.  The  Arabic  is  in 
large  Naskhl  script  and  the  Persian  in  TaTIq. 

Contains  the  7th  Juz'.  On  the  first  page  there  is  a  design  with  a  circle  in 
blue.  First  two  pages  illuminated  in  blue  and  gold  with  the  Arabic  words 
written  in  gold  and  the  Persian  in  red.  Margins  ruled  in  red  and  blue.  Verses 
separated  by  gold  discs.  Name  of  Allah  written  in  gold  whenever  it  occurs. 
Copied  by  Sadiq.  No  binding.  Probably  ninth/fifteenth  century. 

21 

Qur'an  (Mss).  Fragment. 

70  folios,  21.5  x  35.5,  7  and  1 1  lines  to  a  page  in  RayhanI  and  Muhaqqaq 
scripts  with  diacritical  marks  in  black. 

The  calligrapher  of  this  Qur'an  is  Shaykh  Hamdullah,  d.  1520  who  per- 
fected the  six  scripts  most  used  in  Turkey  and  the  Arab  world.  The  first  two 
pages  contain  a  dedication  to  Prince  Firiiz  Agha  written  in  gold  on  a  strik- 
ingly deep  blue  background.  A  one  page  Fatihah  (The  Opening)  written  on  a 
gilt  background  with  soft  floral  designs.  The  text  starts  with  verse  13  of  Surat 
al-Anam  (Cattle).  The  number  of  lines  changes  to  eleven  on  the  pages  of 
Surat  Saba'  (Saba')  and  Surat  al-Malaikah  (The  Angels).  On  these  pages 
lines  one,  six,  and  eleven  are  placed  in  decorated  panels.  Verses  separated  by 
gold  discs.  Paper  in  pink  color.

Muhaqqaq  script  in  alternating  blue  and  gold,  remainder  of  text  on  each  page 
written  in  small  Naskhl  script  with  diacritics  in  black  and  red.  Contains  the 
surahs  of  Yasin  (Yasin),  al-Fath  (Victory),  al-Waqiah  (The  Event).  Illumi-

tenth/sixteenth  century  from  Iran.  SM80

Quran  (Facsimile). 

286  folios,  13.5  x  17  cm.,  1 5  lines  to  a  page  in  NaskhT  script  with  diacritical 
marks  in  black. 

Written  in  Baghdad  in  391/1001  by  'All  ibn  Hilal  better  known  as  Ibn 
al-Bawwab,  d.  1022?  This  is  the  earliest  known  Qur'an  in  NaskhT  script  by  the 
calligrapher  who  perfected  Ibn  Muqlah's  Khatt  al-Mansub.  There  are  five 
pairs  of  decorated  pages,  three  double  pages  at  the  beginning  and  two  at  the 
end.  Two  pairs  of  pages  contain  only  ornaments,  the  others  ornaments  and 
script.  Titles  of  surahs  written  in  gold.  Designs  of  rosettes  decorate  the  margins 
and  palmettes  the  titles  of  surahs.  The  binding  is  in  brown  leather  with 
geometrical  designs. 

31 

Qur'an  (Facsimile). 

476  pages,  18  x  29  cm.,  15  lines  to  a  page  in  NaskhT  and  Thuluth  scripts 
with  diacritics  in  black. 

The  original  manuscript  kept  at  the  Topkapi  Serai  Museum  was  done  by 
the  famous  Ahmed  Karahisari,  1520,  for  the  Ottoman  Sultan  Sulayman  the 
Magnificient.  This  beautiful  copy  of  the  Qur'an  is  decorated  in  the  best 
tradition  of  Ottoman  style  and  illuminated  throughout  in  gold  and  colors  in 
mainly  floral  and  Arabesque  designs  with  the  blue  color  dominating.  Headings 
mainly  copied  in  Thuluth.  Borders  ruled  with  gold.  Binding  handmade  and 
blind-tooled  of  pure  goat  leather.  Copy  housed  in  a  handmade  case.

printed  on  the  island  of  Bandar  al-Munbi'  in  al-Matba'  al-Karimi.  The  date 
is  not  clear.  It  is  written  out  as  1 1 13  A.H.  but  the  numerals  indicate  1310  A.H.

said  that  this  copy  was  caputred  on  the  island  of  Jolo  (The  Philippines)  during 
General  Leonard  Wood's  expedition  against  the  moros  in  1903.

In  process 

The  world's  great  religions,  no.  4. 

Eastman  color. 

Based  on  the  article  The  world  of  Islam,  which  appeared  in  Life  magazine, 
May  9,  1955. 

Summary:  Captioned  photographs  and  drawings  are  used  in  tracing  the 
development  of  the  Islami  religion  into  one  of  the  world's  great  religions;  in 
presenting  the  five  basic  observances  of  Islam;  and  in  discussing  the  teachings 
of  the  Koran.  Shows  Moslems  celebrating  Mohammed's  birthday  and  the 
circumcision  of  a  male  infant;  describes  traditional  rites  surrounding  a  funeral; 
shows  mystics  participating  in  ritualistic  dances.  Explains  that  the  custom  of 
keeping  women  in  seclusion  is  becoming  less  strict  in  many  countries.  Includes 
views  of  the  Dome  of  the  Rock  in  Jerusalem. 

Credits:  Photographs:  David  Duncan  and  others.  Art  work  and  map:  Anto- 
nio Petruccelli.

210 


The  frontispiece  of  a  facsimile  of  the  Holy  Qur'an  calligraphed  and  illuminated  by 
al-Hajj  Zuhayr  Bash  Mamluk,  d.  1885.  Written  in  Maghribi  script.  This  Qur'an 
presents  a  distinctive  peculiarity.  On  each  page  certain  words  or  clusters  of  words 
are  colored  in  red.  Every  time  we  open  the  volume  flat,  these  words  or  clusters  on 
the  right  side  page,  an  even-numbered  page,  would  show  exactly  at  the 
corresponding  place  on  the  left  side  page,  the  odd-numbered  page. 

Surat  al-Fatihah  (The  Opening)  and  Surat  al-Baqarah  (The  Cow)  II:  1-4.

A  page  of  a  facsimile  edition  of  a  16th  century  Qur'an  written  by  Muhammad  ibn 
Na'im  (Ruzbihan).  It  is  one  of  the  finest  manuscripts  of  the  early  Saf avid  period 
(1502-1748) .  Ibn  Na'im  illuminated  his  script  by  using  floral  Arabesques.  This 
manuscript  is  remarkable  for  the  variety  of  illumination  and  colors. 

Surat  al  Fdtihah (The  Opening)  and  Surat  al-Baqarah  (The  Cow)  II;  1-3.
